questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of right wrist pain and swelling 2 hours after falling on an outstretched hand while playing softball. The pain worsened when he attempted to pitch after the fall. He has eczema and type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and topical clobetasol. He appears uncomfortable. Examination shows multiple lichenified lesions over his forearms. The right wrist is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. There is tenderness to palpation in the area between the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, and extensor pollicis longus muscle. The thumb can be opposed actively toward the other fingers. Muscle strength of the right hand is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Colles fracture commonly occurs after a fall on an outstretched dorsiflexed hand. Patients with a Colles fracture typically present with pain localized to the distal radius, in contrast to this patient's pain. Additional findings with a Colles fracture may include radial angulation of the wrist and abnormal positioning of the wrist.
Image Description:

Fracture of the distal radius with radial and dorsal displacement. Commonly a result of falling onto the extended wrist.

B) INCORRECT:

A transscaphoid perilunate dislocation results from ligament tears in the wrist after a fall on a hyperextended wrist. Patients present with pain in the region of the lunate with limited wrist motion, and may also complain of paresthesias within the distribution of the median nerve. Also, patients with transscaphoid perilunate dislocation do not present with pain while applying pressure to the snuff box, making it an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray right wrist (PA view)

The scaphoid (yellow overlay) is seen as two overlapping fragments as a result of a waist fracture, and the lunate (blue overlay) has a triangular shape (termed the piece of pie sign). A triangular lunate can be seen in both lunate and perilunate dislocations, which can be better differentiated with the addition of a lateral view.

C: capitate; R: radius; U: ulna

C) INCORRECT:

Fractures of the trapezium and the distal carpal row make up a small portion of injuries to the carpal bones. Pain from a trapezium fracture can be elicited from the dorsal aspect of the bone at the base of the thumb, and there is typically weakness when pinching (OK sign). The localization of this patient's pain is inconsistent with a trapezium fracture.
Image Description:

X-ray of the base of thumb and radial side of carpus (left hand; a: AP view; b: lateral view)

A comminuted fracture (red lines) of the trapezium with a collapsed articular surface (green lines) is accompanied by dislocation (indicated by arrow) at the carpal-metacarpal joint.

D) CORRECT:

Scaphoid fractures typically occur following a fall on an outstretched hand. If pain occurs in the anatomical snuffbox after trauma, the injury should be treated as a scaphoid fracture until proven otherwise to prevent possible complications such as avascular necrosis and bone nonunion. Initial x-rays do not reveal the fracture in up to 20% of cases. Treatment of nondisplaced fractures or displaced fractures < 1 mm consists of wrist immobilization via thumb spica cast for a minimum of 6–8 weeks with x-ray reevaluation after approx. 2 weeks. Indications for surgical treatment with internal fixation include open fractures, proximal pole fractures, displaced fractures > 1 mm, instability of the carpal bones, rupture of the scapholunate ligament, and late presentation (> 4 weeks of fracture onset).
Image Description:

A triangular depression over the dorsal aspect of the base of the thumb that becomes prominent when the thumb is extended or abducted.

Boundaries: tendon of the extensor pollicis longus (on the ulnar side) and the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and the abductor pollicis longus (radial side)

The scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. Tenderness on application of pressure to the anatomical snuffbox is a clinical sign of a scaphoid fracture.

E) INCORRECT:

De Quervain tenosynovitis is a common cause of atraumatic pain on the radial aspect of the wrist. The history of acute pain associated with trauma in this patient makes this diagnosis less likely.
Image Description:

Noninflammatory thickening of the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis in the first dorsal compartment of the extensor retinaculum, overlying the radial styloid process.

F) INCORRECT:

A lunate dislocation presents with pain and swelling on the volar aspect of the lunate. It may also present with acute carpal tunnel syndrome due to volar swelling. Unlike a perilunate dislocation, radioulnar articulation is not preserved. The localization of pain in this patient's examination is not consistent with lunate dislocation.
Image Description:

X-ray wrist (left: PA view; right: lateral view)

The lunate (dashed outline) is displaced and rotated volarly, creating the classic triangular piece-of-pie sign of lunate dislocation on the PA view. Widening of the scapholunate interval (yellow overlay) is also seen. Volar angulation and displacement of the lunate are also seen on the lateral view, producing the spilled teacup appearance.

A displaced radial styloid fracture (green overlay and red line) is also visible.
questions.hint: Wrist pain after a fall on an outstretched hand and tenderness on palpation of the anatomical snuffbox with decreased grip strength indicates a carpal bone fracture in this anatomical region.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of left wrist pain and swelling for 5 hours. She fell on an outstretched hand while playing basketball. She ignored it initially as she thought it was just a bruise, but the pain and swelling worsened throughout the day. The analgesic spray she used did not provide adequate relief. There is no family history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive pill. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a swollen and tender left wrist; range of motion is limited. The anatomical snuffbox is tender to palpation. The grip strength of the left hand is decreased. The thumb can be opposed toward the other fingers. Finkelstein test is negative. X-rays of the wrist show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Thumb spica cast and repeat x-rays in 2 weeks
Rest, ice, and repeat x-rays in 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and internal fixation with K-wires or screws is the treatment of choice in the following cases: all displaced scaphoid fractures, fractures that involve the proximal pole of the scaphoid, and/or scaphoid fractures associated with perilunate injuries (e.g., scapholunate dislocation, scapholunate ligament tears). However, the wrist x-ray in this patient is inconclusive. In this situation, a different, less invasive approach is preferable until the scaphoid fracture, as well as the exact location of the fracture line, can be radiologically confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroid injections may be used as a first-line treatment in patients with de Quervain tenosynovitis. Patients with de Quervain tenosynovitis may present with wrist pain. However, de Quervain tenosynovitis is most commonly an overuse injury and typically occurs in individuals between 30–50 years of age. Moreover, patients with de Quervain tenosynovitis would present with tenderness over the radial styloid process (not the base of the thumb) and a positive Finkelstein test.

C) INCORRECT:

Following a scaphoid fracture, radial styloidectomy is only indicated in patients with arthritis of the wrist joint as a result of nonunion and avascular necrosis of the scaphoid. Although these complications are common among patients with scaphoid fractures, they are unlikely to occur immediately following the injury.

D) CORRECT:

If there is strong suspicion for a scaphoid fracture, immobilization of the thumb and wrist with a thumb spica cast is indicated even if there are initially no x-ray findings of a scaphoid fracture. This procedure is important because a delay in immobilization increases the risk of complications such as nonunion and avascular necrosis of the scaphoid. A repeat wrist x-ray after approx. 2 weeks is recommended to confirm the diagnosis of a scaphoid fracture.

In some cases, an MRI may be considered for potentially more conclusive findings than x-rays if the patient does not want to wear a cast and wait 2 weeks for reevaluation based on a suspected diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray hand (PA view)

A nondisplaced fracture (red line) is visible through the waist of the scaphoid bone of the wrist.

E) INCORRECT:

A wrist x-ray should be repeated after 2 weeks to confirm the diagnosis of a scaphoid fracture. However, in a patient with a history suggestive of a scaphoid fracture, conservative management with rest and ice only is insufficient because of the increased risk of complications, such as nonunion and avascular necrosis of the scaphoid. Another measure is needed to prevent these complications.

F) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous pinning with K-wires or cannulated screws may be used to treat undisplaced fractures involving the wrist or distal pole of the scaphoid, especially in individuals who wish to avoid prolonged immobilization with a cast. However, the wrist x-ray does not show a scaphoid fracture, and the site of the fracture is not known. In this situation, a different, less invasive approach is preferable until the scaphoid fracture, as well as the exact location of the fracture line, can be radiologically confirmed.
questions.hint: Wrist pain, anatomical snuffbox tenderness, and weak grip strength after a fall on an outstretched hand are highly suggestive of a scaphoid fracture. Wrist x-rays are inconclusive in up to 25% of patients with a scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of right wrist pain after a fall from a ladder. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength and tenderness between the tendons of extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis. X-ray of the right wrist shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?

choices.text: Paralysis of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle
Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid bone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of the abductor pollicis brevis is a feature of median nerve palsy, which can occur following a fall on the hand due to compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel by a dislocated lunate. However, lunate dislocation would cause swelling in the wrist with restriction of the range of motion, and the dislocated lunate would be clearly visible on x-ray. This patient with pain in the anatomical snuffbox and a normal initial x-ray most likely has a different injury.
Image Description:

X-ray wrist (left: PA view; right: lateral view)

The lunate (dashed outline) is displaced and rotated volarly, creating the classic triangular piece-of-pie sign of lunate dislocation on the PA view. Widening of the scapholunate interval (yellow overlay) is also seen. Volar angulation and displacement of the lunate are also seen on the lateral view, producing the spilled teacup appearance.

A displaced radial styloid fracture (green overlay and red line) is also visible.

B) CORRECT:

Decreased grip strength with pain in the anatomical snuffbox suggests a scaphoid fracture, which is typically caused by falling onto an outstretched hand. The scaphoid bone, which is one of the carpal bones that forms the radiocarpal joint, receives its blood supply from an end artery that runs in a distal to proximal direction. A fracture of the scaphoid can damage this branch of the radial artery and cause avascular necrosis of the proximal segment. Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid increases the risk of osteoarthritis of the radiocarpal joint. The initial x-ray in the case of scaphoid fracture can be normal. Therefore, patients with a normal x-ray should be followed up with a repeat x-ray after approx. 2 weeks or an MRI if a scaphoid fracture is strongly suspected.
Image Description:

The scaphoid is supplied primarily by branches of the radial artery. As illustrated here, the superficial palmar branch penetrates the bone from the palmar side and the dorsal carpal branch from the dorsal side, both at the distal pole. There may, however, be significant variation, both in which radial branches are the principal contributors and in their branching patterns.

Because the arterial blood supply of the scaphoid flows from the distal pole to the proximal pole, more proximal scaphoid fractures are at higher risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Avascular necrosis leading to the collapse of the lunate is seen in Kienbock disease, a condition that is associated with repetitive impact to the hand (e.g., playing volleyball). This patient with pain in the anatomic snuff box after acute trauma is most likely to develop avascular necrosis of the scaphoid, not the lunate.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypesthesia of the hypothenar eminence is a feature of ulnar nerve palsy, which can occur following a fall on the hand due to compression of the ulnar nerve by a fractured hook of hamate. Hook of hamate fractures can cause decreased grip strength, and the initial wrist x-ray can be normal in anteroposterior and lateral views. However, patients with a hook of hamate fracture would have tenderness on the palmar surface of the hand at the site of the hamate. This patient with pain in the anatomical snuffbox (dorsal surface of the hand) most likely has a different injury.
Image Description:

The carpal bones are numbered consecutively, with the distal row highlighted in blue.

E) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for contraction of the palmar aponeurosis (Dupuytren contracture) are repetitive trauma, cigarette smoking, heavy alcohol use, diabetes mellitus, and autoimmune diseases. This patient's injury is not a risk factor for Dupuytren contracture.
questions.hint: The region between the tendons of extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis is called the anatomical snuff box.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of left wrist pain and swelling that started immediately after a fall. She was walking her dog when the dog abruptly pulled away, causing her to fall forward onto both hands. Physical examination shows left wrist pain with pinching and grasping, moderate swelling, and mild tenderness. Her left thumb is placed in a thumb immobilization splint. An x-ray of the wrist 2 days later is shown. The most likely cause of these findings is a fracture of which of the following bones?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone. Fracture results from an axial load injury onto a hyperextended and radially deviated wrist and manifests with mild wrist pain, swelling, and painful pinching and grasping, as seen in this patient. Although many scaphoid fractures can be treated conservatively with immobilization, proximal pole fractures carry a high risk of avascular necrosis and often require surgical fixation.
Image Description:

A triangular depression over the dorsal aspect of the base of the thumb that becomes prominent when the thumb is extended or abducted.

Boundaries: tendon of the extensor pollicis longus (on the ulnar side) and the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and the abductor pollicis longus (radial side)

The scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. Tenderness on application of pressure to the anatomical snuffbox is a clinical sign of a scaphoid fracture.

B) INCORRECT:

A fracture of the ulna is often caused by a direct blow to or a fall onto a pronated forearm. These fractures result in localized pain, swelling, and often gross deformation and/or loss of range of motion at the forearm or wrist. Although this patient has wrist pain and swelling, the mechanism of injury makes an ulnar fracture less likely. Furthermore, the x-ray does not show an ulnar fracture.
Image Description:

X-ray forearm (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a child

An isolated fracture of the mid ulnar diaphysis is accompanied by displacement of the distal fragment (indicated by arrows). There is no disruption of the distal radioulnar joint.

This type of fracture has been termed a “parry” or “nightstick fracture.” It occurs when the ulna is more exposed than the radius to injury. It may be the result of direct trauma (forearm raised in self-defense) or indirect trauma (fall).

Arrowheads: bracelet; R: radius; U: ulnar

C) INCORRECT:

A fracture of the distal radius (e.g., Colles fracture) can be caused by an axial load injury onto a hyperextended wrist, particularly in patients with osteoporosis or those who have sustained a high-energy trauma. Distal radius fractures manifest with wrist pain, swelling, and grasp deficits. However, this patient's young age and low-energy mechanism of injury make a Colles fracture less likely. Furthermore, the x-ray shows no fracture at the distal radius.
Image Description:

X-ray wrist (left: PA view; right: lateral view) after a fall onto an outstretched hand

A metaphyseal fracture of the distal radius (green line) shows dorsal angulation of the distal fragment and impaction. (The vertical white line represents the axis of the radius. The horizontal white line represents the right angle that the radial articular surface physiologically stands at. The dotted white line illustrates the dorsal angulation of the distal fragment.) This type of fracture has been termed a Colles fracture. The pronator quadratus fat pad is displaced and seen as a convex lucency (red curved line). A fracture of the ulnar styloid is also present (white arrow).

D) INCORRECT:

Lunate fractures and perilunate dislocations are rare injuries resulting from high-energy trauma to a hyperextended and ulnar deviated wrist. Patients present with wrist pain, swelling, and occasionally median nerve injuries such as acute carpal tunnel syndrome. Although this patient has wrist pain and swelling after an axial load injury, the low-energy mechanism of injury makes a lunate fracture or dislocation less likely. Moreover, the x-ray is inconsistent with a lunate fracture.

E) INCORRECT:

A fracture of the hamate body is a rare carpal bone injury that is usually sustained from direct axial load onto a clenched wrist. It manifests with wrist swelling, ulnar wrist pain, and tenderness over the hamate. Although this patient has wrist pain and swelling after an axial load injury, the fact that her injury involved hyperextension makes a hamate fracture less likely. Moreover, the x-ray shows no fracture at the hamate.
questions.hint: This type of fracture is typically associated with tenderness to palpation of the anatomical snuffbox.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with right wrist pain after a fall from a ladder. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength and tenderness between the tendons of extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis. X-ray of the right wrist shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?

choices.text: Paralysis of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle
Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid bone

A) INCORRECT:

The scaphoid is supplied primarily by branches of the radial artery. C) INCORRECT:

Avascular necrosis leading to the collapse of the lunate is seen in Kienbock disease, a condition that is associated with repetitive impact to the hand (e.g., playing volleyball). D) INCORRECT:

Hypesthesia of the hypothenar eminence is a feature of ulnar nerve palsy, which can occur following a fall on the hand due to compression of the ulnar nerve by a fractured hook of hamate. Hook of hamate fractures can cause decreased grip strength, and the initial wrist x-ray can be normal in anteroposterior and lateral views. However, patients with a hook of hamate fracture would have tenderness on the palmar surface of the hand at the site of the hamate. This patient with pain in the anatomical snuffbox (dorsal surface of the hand) most likely has a different injury.
Image Description:

The carpal bones are numbered consecutively, with the distal row highlighted in blue.

E) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for contraction of the palmar aponeurosis (Dupuytren contracture) are repetitive trauma, cigarette smoking, heavy alcohol use, diabetes mellitus, and autoimmune diseases. This patient's injury is not a risk factor for Dupuytren contracture.
questions.hint: The region between the tendons of extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis is called the anatomical snuff box.

The analgesic spray she used did not provide adequate relief. She appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left wrist; range of motion is limited. questions.hint: Wrist pain after a fall on an outstretched hand and tenderness on palpation of the anatomical snuffbox with decreased grip strength indicates a carpal bone fracture in this anatomical region.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with left wrist pain after a fall onto an outstretched hand while playing basketball. He reports immediate pain and difficulty moving his wrist. On examination, there is swelling, mild bruising, and localized tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox with limited range of motion. He denies numbness or tingling. Plain radiographs are inconclusive.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A distal radius fracture often results from a fall on an outstretched hand and typically presents with a visible deformity, such as a 'dinner fork' appearance, and is usually evident on radiographs. The absence of these findings and the presence of snuffbox tenderness make a scaphoid fracture more likely.

B) CORRECT:

A scaphoid fracture manifests with tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox, especially after a fall on an outstretched hand. This bone is prone to injury in young adults during high-impact activities. The scaphoid's retrograde blood supply increases the risk of complications like non-union or avascular necrosis if not promptly treated. Although initial radiographs may not show the fracture, the clinical presentation strongly suggests a scaphoid fracture. Further imaging, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or follow-up radiographs, is often necessary to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

Key learning point: Tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox following a fall on an outstretched hand is highly suggestive of a scaphoid fracture.

C) INCORRECT:

Wrist sprains can present with pain and swelling after trauma, but they usually cause diffuse tenderness rather than localized snuffbox tenderness. The specific tenderness and mechanism of injury suggest a bony injury, such as a scaphoid fracture, rather than a simple sprain.

D) INCORRECT:

Lunate dislocation typically presents with signs of median nerve compression, such as numbness or tingling, and distinct radiographic abnormalities. The absence of these symptoms and inconclusive radiographs make a scaphoid fracture more likely than a lunate dislocation.

questions.text: You are seeing a 36-year-old woman in the emergency department for left wrist pain and swelling that began immediately after a fall. She reports that while walking her dog, the dog suddenly pulled away, causing her to fall forward onto both hands. On examination, she has left wrist pain with pinching and grasping, moderate swelling, and mild tenderness. Her left thumb is immobilized in a splint. An x-ray of the wrist taken 2 days later is provided. Which one of the following bones is most likely fractured in this scenario?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fracture of the distal radius (e.g., Colles fracture) can be caused by an axial load injury onto a hyperextended wrist, particularly in patients with osteoporosis or those who have sustained a high-energy trauma. Distal radius fractures manifest with wrist pain, swelling, and grasp deficits. However, this patient's young age and low-energy mechanism of injury make a Colles fracture less likely. Furthermore, the x-ray shows no fracture at the distal radius.

B) INCORRECT:

A fracture of the ulna is often caused by a direct blow to or a fall onto a pronated forearm. These fractures result in localized pain, swelling, and often gross deformation and/or loss of range of motion at the forearm or wrist. Although this patient has wrist pain and swelling, the mechanism of injury makes an ulnar fracture less likely. Furthermore, the x-ray does not show an ulnar fracture.

C) CORRECT:

The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone. Fracture results from an axial load injury onto a hyperextended and radially deviated wrist and manifests with mild wrist pain, swelling, and painful pinching and grasping, as seen in this patient. Although many scaphoid fractures can be treated conservatively with immobilization, proximal pole fractures carry a high risk of avascular necrosis and often require surgical fixation.

Key learning point: A fall onto an outstretched, hyperextended wrist commonly causes a scaphoid fracture, which presents with wrist pain, swelling, and tenderness, and carries a risk of avascular necrosis if the proximal pole is involved.
Image Description:

A triangular depression over the dorsal aspect of the base of the thumb that becomes prominent when the thumb is extended or abducted.

Boundaries: tendon of the extensor pollicis longus (on the ulnar side) and the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and the abductor pollicis longus (radial side)

The scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. Tenderness on application of pressure to the anatomical snuffbox is a clinical sign of a scaphoid fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

Lunate fractures and perilunate dislocations are rare injuries resulting from high-energy trauma to a hyperextended and ulnar deviated wrist. Patients present with wrist pain, swelling, and occasionally median nerve injuries such as acute carpal tunnel syndrome. Although this patient has wrist pain and swelling after an axial load injury, the low-energy mechanism of injury makes a lunate fracture or dislocation less likely. Moreover, the x-ray is inconsistent with a lunate fracture.

E) INCORRECT:

A fracture of the hamate body is a rare carpal bone injury that is usually sustained from direct axial load onto a clenched wrist. It manifests with wrist swelling, ulnar wrist pain, and tenderness over the hamate. Although this patient has wrist pain and swelling after an axial load injury, the fact that her injury involved hyperextension makes a hamate fracture less likely. Moreover, the x-ray shows no fracture at the hamate.
questions.hint: This type of fracture is typically associated with tenderness to palpation of the anatomical snuffbox.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to your clinic with right wrist pain after falling from a ladder. On examination, he has decreased grip strength and tenderness between the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis. X-ray of the right wrist is normal. This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following complications?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid bone.
Paralysis of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for contraction of the palmar aponeurosis (Dupuytren contracture) are repetitive trauma, cigarette smoking, heavy alcohol use, diabetes mellitus, and autoimmune diseases. This patient's injury is not a risk factor for Dupuytren contracture.

B) CORRECT:

Decreased grip strength with pain in the anatomical snuffbox suggests a scaphoid fracture, which is typically caused by falling onto an outstretched hand. The scaphoid bone, which is one of the carpal bones that forms the radiocarpal joint, receives its blood supply from an end artery that runs in a distal to proximal direction. A fracture of the scaphoid can damage this branch of the radial artery and cause avascular necrosis of the proximal segment. Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid increases the risk of osteoarthritis of the radiocarpal joint. The initial x-ray in the case of scaphoid fracture can be normal. Therefore, patients with a normal x-ray should be followed up with a repeat x-ray after approx. 2 weeks or an MRI if a scaphoid fracture is strongly suspected.

Key learning point: Scaphoid fractures are at high risk for avascular necrosis of the proximal bone segment due to disruption of its retrograde blood supply.
Image Description:

The scaphoid is supplied primarily by branches of the radial artery. As illustrated here, the superficial palmar branch penetrates the bone from the palmar side and the dorsal carpal branch from the dorsal side, both at the distal pole. There may, however, be significant variation, both in which radial branches are the principal contributors and in their branching patterns.

Because the arterial blood supply of the scaphoid flows from the distal pole to the proximal pole, more proximal scaphoid fractures are at higher risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypesthesia of the hypothenar eminence is a feature of ulnar nerve palsy, which can occur following a fall on the hand due to compression of the ulnar nerve by a fractured hook of hamate. Hook of hamate fractures can cause decreased grip strength, and the initial wrist x-ray can be normal in anteroposterior and lateral views. However, patients with a hook of hamate fracture would have tenderness on the palmar surface of the hand at the site of the hamate. This patient with pain in the anatomical snuffbox (dorsal surface of the hand) most likely has a different injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of the abductor pollicis brevis is a feature of median nerve palsy, which can occur following a fall on the hand due to compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel by a dislocated lunate. However, lunate dislocation would cause swelling in the wrist with restriction of the range of motion, and the dislocated lunate would be clearly visible on x-ray. This patient with pain in the anatomical snuffbox and a normal initial x-ray most likely has a different injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Avascular necrosis leading to the collapse of the lunate is seen in Kienbock disease, a condition that is associated with repetitive impact to the hand (e.g., playing volleyball). This patient with pain in the anatomic snuff box after acute trauma is most likely to develop avascular necrosis of the scaphoid, not the lunate.
questions.hint: The region between the tendons of extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis is called the anatomical snuff box.

questions.text: You are seeing a 19-year-old man in the emergency department who presents with right wrist pain and swelling that began 2 hours ago after he fell on an outstretched hand while playing softball. He reports that the pain worsened when he tried to pitch after the fall. On examination, he appears uncomfortable. The right wrist is swollen and tender, with limited range of motion due to pain. There is tenderness to palpation in the area between the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, and extensor pollicis longus muscles. He is able to actively oppose his thumb toward the other fingers. Muscle strength in the right hand is decreased. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A lunate dislocation presents with pain and swelling on the volar aspect of the lunate. It may also present with acute carpal tunnel syndrome due to volar swelling. Unlike a perilunate dislocation, radioulnar articulation is not preserved. The localization of pain in this patient's examination is not consistent with lunate dislocation.

B) INCORRECT:

A Colles fracture commonly occurs after a fall on an outstretched dorsiflexed hand. Patients with a Colles fracture typically present with pain localized to the distal radius, in contrast to this patient's pain. Additional findings with a Colles fracture may include radial angulation of the wrist and abnormal positioning of the wrist.

C) INCORRECT:

De Quervain tenosynovitis is a common cause of atraumatic pain on the radial aspect of the wrist. The history of acute pain associated with trauma in this patient makes this diagnosis less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Fractures of the trapezium and the distal carpal row make up a small portion of injuries to the carpal bones. Pain from a trapezium fracture can be elicited from the dorsal aspect of the bone at the base of the thumb, and there is typically weakness when pinching (OK sign). The localization of this patient's pain is inconsistent with a trapezium fracture.

E) CORRECT:

Scaphoid fractures typically occur following a fall on an outstretched hand. If pain occurs in the anatomical snuffbox after trauma, the injury should be treated as a scaphoid fracture until proven otherwise to prevent possible complications such as avascular necrosis and bone nonunion. Initial x-rays do not reveal the fracture in up to 20% of cases. Treatment of nondisplaced fractures or displaced fractures < 1 mm consists of wrist immobilization via thumb spica cast for a minimum of 6–8 weeks with x-ray reevaluation after approx. 2 weeks. Indications for surgical treatment with internal fixation include open fractures, proximal pole fractures, displaced fractures > 1 mm, instability of the carpal bones, rupture of the scapholunate ligament, and late presentation (> 4 weeks of fracture onset).

Key learning point: Scaphoid fracture should be suspected after a fall on an outstretched hand with anatomical snuffbox tenderness, as missed diagnosis can lead to avascular necrosis and nonunion.
Image Description:

A triangular depression over the dorsal aspect of the base of the thumb that becomes prominent when the thumb is extended or abducted.

Boundaries: tendon of the extensor pollicis longus (on the ulnar side) and the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and the abductor pollicis longus (radial side)

The scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. Tenderness on application of pressure to the anatomical snuffbox is a clinical sign of a scaphoid fracture.
questions.hint: Wrist pain after a fall on an outstretched hand and tenderness on palpation of the anatomical snuffbox with decreased grip strength indicates a carpal bone fracture in this anatomical region.

questions.text: A 22-year-old competitive rock climber presents with wrist pain after falling from a boulder 3 days ago. She initially attributed the pain to a bruise but now reports persistent aching, especially when gripping objects. Physical examination shows tenderness over the anatomical snuffbox and a positive scaphoid compression test. Initial x-rays, including posteroanterior, lateral, oblique, and scaphoid views, show no fracture. The patient asks about returning to climbing next week for a competition. Which factor has the greatest influence on the management decision?

choices.text: Patient’s desire to return to activity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although age can influence healing rates and treatment approaches, it is not the primary factor for determining immediate management in suspected scaphoid fractures. Clinical signs suggestive of a fracture take precedence over the patient's age in initial management decisions.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Anatomical snuffbox tenderness after wrist trauma is the key clinical finding that determines management. This finding is highly suggestive of a scaphoid fracture, even if initial x-rays are negative. Immobilization in a thumb spica cast is warranted until a fracture is definitively ruled out through follow-up imaging or clinical reassessment.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the 3-day delay may affect healing outcomes, the timing of injury onset does not change the immediate management approach when clinical findings suggest a scaphoid fracture. The standard protocol is immobilization regardless of when the injury occurred.

D) INCORRECT:

Negative initial x-rays do not rule out a scaphoid fracture, as 15–20% of scaphoid fractures are undetectable on initial x-rays. Clinical signs suggestive of a fracture take precedence over negative imaging in determining the management approach.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the patient wants to compete next week, this does not change the immediate management, which prioritizes proper immobilization to prevent complications from a possible fracture. Rushing a return to activity without adequate healing risks long-term damage.
